Unknown translator from the Northern Liang Dynasty
Thus have I heard: Once the Buddha was at RÄjagá¹›ha, on the Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain,
together with a great assembly of ten thousand bhiká¹£us, all of whom had attained the path of arhatship, their names being ÅšÄriputra, MahÄmaudgalyÄyana, SubhÅ«ti, and others like them;
there were also two thousand bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, their names being Vimukti Bodhisattva, CittamatÄ« Bodhisattva, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada Bodhisattva, and others like them;
there were also eighty thousand elders, their names being Brahmacarya Elder, MahÄbrahmacarya Elder, and Dhá¹›á¹­aka Elder, and others like them;
there were also sixty million koá¹­is of devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans.

At that time, the Venerable One was surrounded by the great assembly, expounding a Mahayana sutra called The Ultimate Reality of the Single Flavor, True, Signless, and Birthless, the Fundamental Awareness of Benefit and Action.

If one hears this sutra, and upholds even a single four-line verse, this person will enter the stage of the Buddha's wisdom, be able to teach and transform sentient beings with skillful means, and become a great spiritual friend for all sentient beings.
After the Buddha had spoken this sutra, he sat in the vajra samÄdhi with his legs crossed, his body and mind unmoving.
At that time, in the assembly there was a bhiká¹£u named A-gÄ-tÄ. He rose from his seat, joined his palms, knelt down, and wanted to reiterate this meaning, speaking a verse, saying:
The Honored One, replete with great kindness, with unobstructed wisdom,
In order to widely liberate sentient beings, expounds the meaning of the single truth.
All are guided by the single flavor, never by the lesser vehicle,
The meaning and flavor of what is spoken are all free from unreality.
Entering the stage of the Buddha's wisdom, the true reality that is certain,
Those who hear it all transcend the world, and there is none who is not liberated.
Immeasurable bodhisattvas all ferry sentient beings across,
Asking the Buddha in detail for the sake of the multitude, knowing the characteristics of the quiescent extinction of dharmas.
Entering the place of certainty, the skillful means of the wisdom of the TathÄgata,
One should speak for the sake of entering reality, all in accordance with the One Vehicle.
There are no various flavors, just as one rain moistens,
The myriad grasses all flourish, according to their individual natures.
The moistening of the Dharma of one flavor universally nourishes all,
Just as that one rain moistens, all causing the sprouts of bodhi to grow.
Entering the flavor of vajra, realizing the true samÄdhi of the Dharma,
Certainly cutting off doubt and regret, accomplishing the seal of the one Dharma.
At that time, the Venerable One arose from samÄdhi and spoke these words:
The wisdom ground of the buddhas enters the true characteristics of dharmas, because of the nature of certainty, skillful means and spiritual powers are all beneficial without characteristics.

The meaning of one enlightenment is difficult to understand and difficult to enter, it is not known or seen by the two vehicles, only buddhas and bodhisattvas are able to know it, and they all speak of one flavor for those sentient beings who can be liberated.
At that time, Bodhisattva Liberation immediately rose from his seat, joined his palms, knelt down, and said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!

If after the Buddha's extinction, the true Dharma passes away and the semblance Dharma abides in the world, in the final age, the five turbidities and sentient beings with many evil karmas revolve in the three realms without a time to escape.
I pray that the Buddha, out of compassion, will proclaim for the sentient beings of later ages the one flavor of certainty and truth, causing those sentient beings to equally attain liberation.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Very good, very good!
Good man!
You are able to ask me about the causes of transcendence, wishing to transform sentient beings, causing those sentient beings to attain the fruits of transcendence.
This is a great matter, inconceivable. Out of great kindness and great compassion, if I do not explain it, I would fall into stinginess and greed.
You all listen single-mindedly, listen attentively, and I will proclaim it for you.
Good man!
If one transforms sentient beings, without generating anything in the transformation, not generating non-transformation, that transformation is great indeed.
Cause those sentient beings to all depart from the mind-self, the mind-self of all is originally empty and quiescent. If one attains the empty mind, the mind does not transform through illusion.
Without illusion, without transformation, one then attains non-arising. The mind of non-arising abides in non-transformation.
Bodhisattva Liberation addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
The nature of sentient beings' minds is originally empty and quiescent. The essence of the empty and quiescent mind is devoid of form and characteristics.
How does one cultivate to attain the originally empty mind?
I only wish that the Buddha, out of compassion, will explain it for me.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!

All mental characteristics are originally without basis, fundamentally without a place of origin, empty and tranquil, unborn. If the mind is unborn, then one enters emptiness and tranquility. The mind-ground of emptiness and tranquility can then attain the emptiness of the mind.
Good man!
The mind without characteristics is without mind, without self. The characteristics of all dharmas are also like this.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If all sentient beings have a self or have a mind, by what Dharma can they be awakened to enable those sentient beings to escape from these bonds?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If there is a self, one should contemplate the twelve links of dependent arising.
The twelve links of dependent arising originally arise from cause and effect. Cause and effect give rise to mental activities.
The mind itself does not even exist, let alone a body.
If there is a self, one should extinguish the view of existence;
If there is no self, let them extinguish the view of non-existence.ğŸ”½If the mind arises, let them extinguish the nature of cessation;
If the mind ceases, let them extinguish the nature of arising.
Extinguishing this view of existence enters into reality.
Why is it so?
Originally arising is not ceasing, originally ceasing is not arising, not ceasing and not arising, not arising and not ceasing, all dharmas are also like this.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
If there are sentient beings who see dharmas arising, what view should they extinguish?
When seeing dharmas ceasing, what view should they extinguish?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!
If there are sentient beings who see dharmas arising, let them extinguish the view of non-existence;
When seeing dharmas ceasing, let them extinguish the view of existence.
If they extinguish this view and attain the true non-existence of dharmas, they enter into the nature of certainty and the certainty of non-arising.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
Causing those sentient beings to abide in non-arising is non-arising.
The Buddha said:
Abiding in non-arising is arising.
Why is it so?
Non-abiding and non-arising are non-arising.
Bodhisattva!
If arising is non-arising, it arises from the arising and ceasing of arising and ceasing, and the original arising is not arising.
The mind is always empty and tranquil, the nature of emptiness is non-abiding, and the mind has no abode, which is non-arising.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
If the mind has no abode, what cultivation and learning is there?
Is there learning?
Or is there no learning?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!

The mind of non-arising has no coming or going, and the original tathÄgatagarbha is inherently tranquil and unmoving. It is neither learning nor non-learning.ğŸ”½There is neither learning nor non-learning, which is precisely non-learning;
Not non-learning is what is to be learned.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
How is the nature of the TathÄgatagarbha inherently still and unmoving?
The Buddha said:
The TathÄgatagarbha, with the characteristics of arising and ceasing cognition hidden, does not manifest the principle. This is the nature of the TathÄgatagarbha inherently still and unmoving.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
What are the characteristics of arising and ceasing cognition?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!
The principle is without what is not necessary.
If there is what is not necessary, then various thoughts arise, with a thousand thoughts and ten thousand considerations, which are the characteristics of arising and ceasing.
Bodhisattva!

Contemplate the inherent nature and characteristics, the principle is naturally complete. A thousand thoughts and ten thousand considerations do not benefit the principle, in vain causing agitation, losing the original mind king.
If there is no thought or consideration, then there is no arising or ceasing.
As it is, do not give rise to the various consciousnesses, peacefully and still, the flowing current not arising, attaining the purity of the five dharmas, this is called the Great Vehicle.
Bodhisattva!
Entering the purity of the five dharmas, the mind is then free from delusion;
If there is no delusion, one enters the ground of the Tathagata's self-realized holy wisdom;
One who enters the ground of wisdom well knows that all things are originally unborn;
Knowing the original non-arising, there is then no delusion.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
If there is no delusion, there should be no cessation.
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!
Delusion is originally unborn, so there is no delusion to cease;
Knowing the mind is no-mind, there is no mind to cease.
Without distinction or separation, the manifesting consciousness does not arise, and there is no arising to cease. This is then non-cessation, yet not non-cessation.
Why is it so?
Because cessation is non-cessation.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
If cessation is non-cessation, cessation is then arising. What is meant by non-arising?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva!
You should stop this arising. Having stopped, there is no stopping, and you do not abide in non-stopping or non-abiding. How is this arising?
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
What is taken and what is abandoned in the mind of non-arising?
In what Dharma characteristics does one abide?
The Buddha said:
The mind of non-arising does not take and does not abandon;
it abides in the non-mind and abides in the non-Dharma.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
How does one abide in the non-mind and abide in the non-Dharma?
The Buddha said:
Not giving rise to the mind is abiding in the non-mind;
not giving rise to the Dharma is abiding in the non-Dharma.
Good man!
The non-arising of the mind and Dharma is precisely non-reliance.
Not abiding in various activities, the mind is always empty and tranquil, without any different characteristics.

It is like empty space, without movement or abiding, without arising or action, without there or here. Attaining the empty mind-eye and the empty Dharma-body, the five aggregates and six sense bases are all empty and tranquil.
Good man!
Those who cultivate the empty Dharma do not rely on the three realms and do not abide in the appearance of precepts;
Pure and without thought, without grasping or releasing;
The nature is equal to vajra, not destroying the Three Jewels;
The empty mind is unmoving, possessing the six pÄramitÄs.
Liberation Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
The six pÄramitÄs all have characteristics.
Can the Dharma with characteristics transcend the world?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The six pÄramitÄs I speak of are without characteristics and unconditioned.
Why is this?
If a person is free from desire, the mind is always pure, and with skillful means of truthful speech, benefiting oneself and benefiting others, this is the pÄramitÄ of giving.
Their aspiration and mindfulness are firm, their minds are always unattached, pure, unstained, and not attached to the three realms - this is the perfection of morality.
Cultivating emptiness to sever bonds, not relying on any existence, peacefully quieting the three karmas, not dwelling in body and mind - this is the perfection of patience.
Far from names and numbers, severing the views of emptiness and existence, deeply entering the emptiness of the aggregates - this is the perfection of vigor.
Equally free from emptiness and quiescence, not dwelling in any emptiness, the mind dwelling in non-attachment, not dwelling in great emptiness - this is the perfection of meditation.
The mind has no characteristics of mind, does not grasp emptiness, all activities do not arise, does not realize quiescence;

The mind has no coming or going, its nature is always equal, the ultimate reality of all dharmas is all of definitive nature, not relying on any stages, not dwelling in wisdom - this is the perfection of wisdom.
Good sons!
These six perfections all attain the fundamental benefit, enter the definitive nature, transcend the world, and have unobstructed liberation.
Good man!
Such characteristics of the Dharma of liberation are all without characteristics or practices, and there is also no liberation or non-liberation. This is called liberation.
Why is it so?
The characteristics of liberation are without characteristics, without practices, without movement, without disturbance, tranquil nirvana, and also not grasping the characteristics of nirvana.

When Liberation Bodhisattva heard these words, his mind was greatly delighted, and he attained something he had never had before. Wishing to proclaim the meaning of the verse, he spoke a verse, saying:
The greatly enlightened and fulfilled Honored One expounds the Dharma for the sake of the assembly,
All speaking of the One Vehicle, without the paths of the Two Vehicles.
One flavor, without characteristics or benefits, just like the great empty space,
Without anything that is not accepted, according to their different natures.
All attain their original places, just like that which is apart from the mind and self,
Accomplished by a single Dharma, all the same and different practices.
All attain their original benefits, extinguishing the two views of existence and nonexistence,
The tranquil nirvana, also not dwelling in grasping and realizing.
Entering the place of certainty, without characteristics, without activity,
The mind of emptiness, the ground of quiescence, the mind of quiescence, unborn.
The same as that vajra nature, not destroying the Three Jewels,
Endowed with the six perfections, liberating all beings.
Soaring above the three realms, all not by the Lesser Vehicle,
The Dharma seal of one taste, accomplished by the One Vehicle.

At that time, the great assembly, hearing this teaching, their minds greatly delighted, attaining freedom from the mind and self, entering emptiness and signlessness, expansive and vast, all attaining certainty, severing bonds and exhausting defilements.

The Vajra SamÄdhi SÅ«tra, Chapter 3: The Practice of Non-arising. At that time, Bodhisattva Mind King, hearing the Buddha speak of the Dharma that transcends the three realms and is inconceivable, rose from his seat, joined his palms, and asked in verse:
The meaning spoken by the TathÄgata is beyond the world and has no characteristics.
Can it be that all beings can exhaust their afflictions?
Cutting off the knots and having an empty mind is non-arising.
How can there be non-arising, yet attain the acceptance of non-arising?
At that time, the Buddha told Bodhisattva Mind King:
Good man!
The acceptance of the Dharma of non-arising is originally unborn. The practices are unborn, not non-arising practices. Attaining the acceptance of non-arising is itself false.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Venerable One!
Attaining the acceptance of non-arising is itself false?
Having nothing to attain and nothing to accept should not be false!
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Good man!
No, it is not.
Why is it so?
If there is no attainment and no acceptance, then there is attainment. If there is attainment and acceptance, then there is birth.
If there is birth in attainment, then all attained dharmas are false.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Venerable One!
How can the mind of no acceptance and no birth not be false?
The Buddha said:
As for the mind of no acceptance and no birth, the mind has no form or substance, just like the nature of fire. Although it is in wood, it is nowhere in particular because of its definitive nature.
It is merely a name, merely a word. The nature cannot be attained. If one wants to explain its principle, one provisionally calls it a name, but the name cannot be attained.
The characteristics of the mind are also like this. One does not see its location. Knowing the mind is like this, then there is no birth in the mind.
Good man!

The nature and characteristics of this mind are also like the Ämalaka fruit. It does not arise from itself, does not arise from others, does not arise from both, does not arise from causes, and does not arise without causes.
Why is this?
Because of the transformation of conditions.
Dependent origination is not arising, the passing of conditions is not ceasing, hidden and manifest are without characteristics, the principle of the faculties is quiescent and extinguished.
Abiding in non-existence, the abode is not seen, because of the determined nature.

This determined nature is also not one, not different, not cut off, not permanent, not entering, not exiting, not arising, not ceasing, free from the four kinds of slander, with the path of language cut off;
The nature of the unborn mind is also like this.
How can it be said that there is arising and non-arising, patience and no patience?
If there is someone who says the mind has attainment, abiding, and seeing, then they will not attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
PrajÃ±Ä is for those who have long understood the nature of the mind to know that the nature of the mind is like this;
The nature is also like this, unborn, and without activity.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Venerable One!
If the mind is originally such, unborn in activity, then all activities are unborn.
The arising of practice does not give rise to non-arising, and non-arising has no practice, which is precisely the practice of non-arising.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Do you use non-arising to realize the practice of non-arising?
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
Why is it so?

As the nature and characteristics of the practice of non-arising are empty and tranquil, there is no seeing, no hearing, no attainment, no loss, no speech, no expression, no knowledge, no characteristics, no grasping, and no abandoning. How can one grasp and realize it?
If one grasps and realizes it, it would be a dispute.
Without dispute and argument, it is the practice of non-arising.
The Buddha said:
You have attained supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Venerable One!
I have not attained supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?
Within the nature of enlightenment, there is no attainment, no loss, no awareness, no knowledge, no characteristics of discrimination. Within non-discrimination is the pure nature.
The nature is without admixture, without speech, neither existent nor non-existent, neither knowledge nor ignorance;
all dharmas and practices are also like this.
Why is it so?
Because all dharma practices do not see a fixed nature in any location.
Originally there is no attainment or non-attainment, so how can one attain anuttarÄ samyaksaá¹ƒbodhi?
The Buddha said:
It is so, it is so.
As you have said, all mental activities do not go beyond the markless, tranquil and unborn essence. The various consciousnesses are also like this.
Why is it so?

The eye and eye contact are all empty and tranquil, and consciousness is also empty and tranquil, without the characteristics of movement or non-movement. Internally, there are no three feelings, and the three feelings are extinguished;
The ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, thought, consciousness, manas, and Älaya consciousness are also like this, all not giving rise to the mind of quiescent extinction or the mind of non-arising.
If one gives rise to the mind of quiescent extinction or the mind of non-arising, this is the practice of arising, not the practice of non-arising.
Bodhisattvas internally give rise to the three feelings, three practices, and three precepts. If they are already quiescent and extinguished, the arising mind does not arise.

The mind is always quiescent and extinguished, without effort and without function. It does not realize the characteristics of quiescent extinction, and also does not abide in non-realization. It can abide in the total retention of signlessness without abiding. Then there are no three feelings, three practices, and three precepts, all of which are quiescent and extinguished, pure and without abiding. It does not enter samÄdhi or abide in sitting meditation, without arising and without practice.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Meditation can gather in agitation and stabilize all illusory disturbances.
Why is it not meditation?
The Buddha said:
Bodhisattva meditation is movement, non-movement and non-meditation is non-arising meditation.
The nature of meditation is unborn, apart from the characteristics of meditation arising;
The nature of meditation is non-abiding, apart from the movement of meditation abiding.
If one knows the nature of meditation to be without movement and stillness, then one attains non-arising;
Non-arising prajÃ±Ä also does not rely on abiding, the mind is also unmoving;
By means of this wisdom, one therefore attains the non-arising prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Bodhisattva Mind King said:
Venerable One!

Non-arising prajÃ±Ä does not abide anywhere, it is not apart from anywhere, the mind has no place to abide, the mind does not abide in a place, without abiding, without mind, the mind is unborn and unstaying.
To abide in the mind like this is to abide in the unborn.
Venerable One!
The unborn and unstaying mind is inconceivable!
Within the inconceivable, can it be said or not?
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is.
Bodhisattva Mind King, hearing these words, marveled at the unprecedented and spoke a verse, saying:
The perfect great wise one extensively explains the Dharma of non-arising,
Hearing what has never been heard before, what was not explained is now explained.
Just like pure nectar, which appears only from time to time,
Difficult to encounter, difficult to conceive, and difficult to hear for those who listen.
The unsurpassed good field of blessings, the supreme excellent medicine,
In order to deliver sentient beings, it is now proclaimed and explained.
At that time, having heard this explanation in the assembly, all attained the non-arising non-arising prajÃ±Ä.

Chapter 4: The Benefits of Original Enlightenment, from the Vajra SamÄdhi SÅ«tra. At that time, Bodhisattva Abiding in No-Dwelling heard the Buddha's explanation of the inconceivable one-flavored truth. He came from far away, sat close to the TathÄgata's seat, single-mindedly contemplated and listened attentively, entered the pure and bright state, and his body and mind were unmoving.
At that time, the Buddha told the Bodhisattva of No-abiding:
Where do you come from?
Where have you now arrived?
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
Venerable One!
I come from the originally unborn, and now arrive at the originally unborn place.
The Buddha said:
You originally did not come from anywhere, and now you originally do not arrive at any place.
You have attained the inconceivable original benefit, and are a great bodhisattva mahasattva.
He then emitted a great light that universally illuminated a thousand worlds, and spoke a verse, saying:
Great is the bodhisattva!
His wisdom is complete.
He always uses the original benefit to benefit sentient beings.
In the four deportments, he always abides in the original benefit, guiding all beings, neither coming nor going.
At that time, the Bodhisattva of No-abiding addressed the Buddha, saying:
Venerable One!
By what beneficial transformation does one transform all the emotional consciousnesses of sentient beings into the amala?
The Buddha said:
The buddhas and tathÄgatas always use the one enlightenment to transform the various consciousnesses into the amala.
Why is it so?

All sentient beings' fundamental enlightenment always uses the one enlightenment to enlighten all sentient beings, enabling them to attain the fundamental enlightenment and awaken to the emptiness and quiescence of the various emotions and consciousnesses.
Why is it so?
The fundamental nature is definitely originally without movement.
The bodhisattva Abiding in Non-Dwelling said:
The eight consciousnesses all arise in dependence on objects. How can they be without movement?
The Buddha said:
All objects are originally empty, and all consciousnesses are originally empty. Emptiness has no nature of conditions. How can they arise in dependence?
The bodhisattva Abiding in Non-Dwelling said:
All objects are empty. How can there be seeing?
The Buddha said:
Seeing is itself false.
Why is it so?
All myriad existences are without arising and without characteristics. They are originally not named and are all empty and quiescent;
The characteristics of all dharmas are also like this;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this.
Since the body does not even exist, how can there be seeing?
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
All objects are empty, all bodies are empty, all consciousnesses are empty, and even awareness should be empty.
The Buddha said:
That which can be aware is indestructible, because its nature is definite. It is neither empty nor not empty, and there is neither emptiness nor non-emptiness.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
All objects are also like this, neither having the characteristic of emptiness nor not having the characteristic of emptiness.
The Buddha said:
So it is.
Those objects that can be cognized have a nature that is originally definite. The definite nature of the faculties has no location.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
Awareness is also like this, having no location.
The Buddha said:
So it is.ğŸ”½Because awareness has no location, it is pure. Purity is without awareness;
Because objects have no location, they are pure. Purity is without form.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
The mind, eyes, and consciousness are also like this.
Inconceivable!
The Buddha said:
The mind, eyes, and consciousness are also like this.
Inconceivable!
Why is it so?
Form has no location, is pure and nameless, and does not enter the inside;
The eyes have no location, are pure and unseen, and do not emerge from the outside;
The mind has no location, is pure and still, and has no place of arising;
Consciousness has no location, is pure and unmoving, and has no separate conditions.
Their nature is all empty and tranquil, and the nature is without awareness. Awareness is then awareness.
Good man!
Awareness and knowledge of non-awareness, the various consciousnesses then enter.
Why is it so?
The vajra wisdom ground severs the path of liberation, and after severing, enters the ground of no-abiding, with no coming or going.

The mind abides nowhere, with a definite nature and ground. That ground is pure like clear lapis lazuli, and its nature is always equal like the great earth. The wondrous observation of awakening is like the sun's wisdom light, and the attainment of the fundamental through benefiting is like the great Dharma rain.
One who enters this wisdom enters the Buddha's ground of wisdom. One who enters the ground of wisdom does not give rise to the various consciousnesses.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
The TathÄgata has said that the one awakening and the holy power, the four vast wisdom grounds, are the fundamental awakening and benefits of all sentient beings.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings are originally complete within this very body.
The Buddha said:
So it is.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings are originally free from defilements, with the fundamental benefits of goodness. Now there are thorns of desire, which have yet to be subdued.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
If there are sentient beings who have not yet attained the fundamental benefits and still have accumulations,
how can they subdue the difficult to subdue?
The Buddha said:

Whether in a group or alone, discriminating and defiled, withdrawing the spirit to dwell in an empty cave, subduing the untamed, liberated from the bonds of Mara, sitting alone in the open, the consciousness aggregate enters parinirvana.
The Bodhisattva of No-abiding said:
The mind attains parinirvana, alone without companions, eternally abiding in parinirvana, one should be liberated.
The Buddha said:
Eternally abiding in parinirvana is bondage to parinirvana.
Why is it so?
The benefit of originally enlightened parinirvana, the originally enlightened benefit of parinirvana, the parinirvana enlightenment factor is the originally enlightened factor.
The nature of enlightenment is no different, parinirvana is no different;
enlightenment is originally unborn, parinirvana is unborn;
enlightenment is originally unceasing, parinirvana is unceasing.
Because of the original parinirvana, there is no attainment of parinirvana, parinirvana is unattainable, how can there be abiding?
Good man!
Enlightenment does not abide in parinirvana.
Why is it so?
Enlightenment is originally unborn, free from the defilements of sentient beings;
The essence of enlightenment is originally quiescent, apart from the movement of nirvana.
Abiding in such a stage, the mind has no abode, no coming or going, and enters the amala consciousness.
The Bodhisattva of No Abiding said:
The amala consciousness is an entrance, and where there is an entrance, there is something to be obtained. This is the Dharma of attainment.
The Buddha said:
No, it is not so.
Why is it so?
It is like a confused child who holds a gold coin in his hand but does not know it exists.
Wandering in the ten directions for fifty years, poor and suffering, solely seeking to sustain himself but not being satisfied.
The father sees the child having such matters and tells the child:
'Why don't you take and use the gold coin you are holding?
You can obtain complete satisfaction according to your needs.'
The child awakens and obtains the gold coin, greatly rejoicing in his heart, thinking he has obtained the money.
The father says to him:
'Confused child!
Do not rejoice. The gold coins you obtained are your own original possessions. Since you have not gained anything, why be happy?
Good man!
The amala fruit is also like this.
Originally without the appearance of coming out, now it is not entering.

These four great functions were spoken by the Buddhas of the past. They are the great bridge and the great ferry crossing.
If one uses this wisdom to transform sentient beings, it is appropriate.

Inconceivable!
Such wisdom benefits oneself and others, transcends the stage of the three realms, does not dwell in nirvana, and enters the bodhisattva path.

Chapter 8: DhÄraá¹‡Ä«, from the Vajra SamÄdhi SÅ«tra, Chapter on DhÄraá¹‡Ä«. At that time, Bodhisattva Earth Treasury rose from the assembly and went to the Buddha's front. Joining palms, kneeling, he addressed the Buddha, saying:
